Since the pioneering work of Wulff and Mosbach more than 30 years ago, molecular imprinting of synthetic polymers has emerged as a robust and convenient way for synthesizing polymeric receptor materials bearing specific recognition sites for target molecules. The resulting materials, molecularly imprinted polymers (MIPs), are therefore commonly referred to as ‘plastic antibodies’. They are obtained by polymerizing a scaffold around a target, or a derivate thereof, which acts as a molecular template. MIPs have been successfully applied in many areas including affinity separation, immunoassays, chemical sensing, solidphase extraction, drug delivery, cell and tissue imaging, direct synthesis and catalysis. In terms of affinity and selectivity, MIPs are on a par with biological receptors like antibodies, and this is accompanied by a superior chemical and physical stability, compatibility with organic media, reusability, easy engineering and low cost. These advantages represent the main reasons for the wide interest raised around molecularly imprinted materials. Mainly produced by free radical polymerization (FRP) of vinyl monomers, MIPs have also taken advantage of the introduction of controlled/living radical polymerization (CRP) techniques, which have literally transformed polymer chemistry over the last decade. This review describes the advantages arising from the use of CRP in synthesizing MIPs, both in terms of sheer binding properties as well as for their remarkable potential for post-polymerization functionalization, for the synthesis of MIP nanomaterials and for the integration of MIPs into composites and hybrid materials. The benefits of using CRP are critically assessed with respect to the still largely applied FRP and guidelines are provided for choosing the most convenient technique to fit a specific targeted application of MIPs.

1. Introduction to molecularly imprinted polymers (MIPs)
Molecular imprinting, according to a widely accepted definition, is the process enabling “the construction of ligand-selective recognition sites in synthetic polymers where a template [. . .] is employed in order to facilitate recognition site formation during the covalent assembly of the bulk phase by a polymerization or polycondensation process, with subsequent removal of some or all of the template being necessary for recognition to occur in the spaces vacated by the templating” [1,2]. This technique allows the creation of specific and selective binding sites possessing a chemical and steric memory of a template. The template can be the target to be recognized by the MIP, or a derivative thereof [3]. The overall process (Fig. 1) is based on two main methods: the “covalent approach”, introduced by Wulff in 1972, and the “non-covalent approach”, developed by Mosbach in the early 80s [4]. The covalent approach is based on the use of a pre-polymerization complex wherein the template is covalently bound to appropriate monomers. After polymerization, the template is removed by chemical cleavage of the covalent complex, and subsequent binding of the target by the MIP takes place through the formation of the same covalent linkages. The main drawback resides in the fact that the covalent bond between the template and the monomers must be easy to break and thus must be formed by a reversible reaction. Compared to the covalent approach, non-covalent imprinting is more versatile and enables the imprinting of a wider range of compounds, although the weaker interactions involved, based mostly on equilibria, are responsible for a more heterogeneous distribution of binding site structures and affinities [1]. Currently, this method is by far the most applied and has become a general synthetic strategy for preparing MIPs [5]. There is also a hybrid approach, in which imprinting follows the covalent route and noncovalent interactions occur during target binding. This strategy has first been reported by Sellergren and Andersson in 1990 [6], and in a modified version including the use of a sacrificial spacer by Whitcombe et al. some years later [7]. This ‘semi-covalent’ approach allows combining some important advantages of both techniques, in particular the high stability of the complex between template and functional monomers during the imprinting step, and the fast interactions occurring during the recognition of the target.
MIPs have historically been inspired by biological recognition systems such as receptors, enzymes, antibodies. With respect to these, MIPs have a number of advantages [8]. Their tailor-made nature, which allows for the recognition of a wide range of targets, is coupled with superior chemical and physical stability, compatibility with organic media, potential reusability, easy engineering and low costs. 2. Controlled/living radical polymerization (CRP) techniques
“Living” polymerization first appeared in 1956, with the pioneering work of Michael Szwarc who introduced the concept of living anionic polymerization to the scientific community and opened the doors to modern polymer science [37]. With this term, he referred to a polymerization process which “does not involve a termination step”, and wherein the macromolecular “growth is” just “interrupted if the supply of monomer is exhausted, although the living ends are potentially able to grow further if any additional amount of monomer is available” [37]. This technique gave the possibility of extending a polymeric chain with consecutive blocks, while providing polymers of unusually low polydispersities. For a long time, living anionic polymerization was the only available method for polymerizing block copolymers. A few decades later, this “living” approach was extended to the cationic (ring opening) polymerization of heterocyclic [38] and polymerization of vinyl monomers [39,40]. Nonetheless, until the introduction of modern CRP, these ionic processes remained the only viable approaches offering a precise control over molecular weight and molecular weight distribution for synthetic polymers. However, their high vulnerability to impurities and moisture, combined with a limited range of suitable monomers (i.e. aprotic, apolar), limited their use.

Nowadays, free radical polymerization represents the most convenient method to synthesize polymers in terms of general setup, reagent purity, range of polymerizable monomers and reaction conditions, and accounts for almost 50% of commercial polymers [41]. Despite these important advantages, FRP does hardly offer any degree of control, mainly because of some ‘side’ reactions affecting the growing species during the polymerization process [42]. Such reactions, i.e. bimolecular termination and chain transfer reactions, strongly compete with the propagation and result in dead polymer chains of very different molecular weights (Scheme 1).
The development of approaches that avoid, or at least keep to a minimum these ‘side’ reactions on propagating radicals is therefore of great interest, since this would favour a homogeneous propagation, which would give the different macromolecules an equal opportunity to grow and to progressively increase their molecular weight with respect to conversion. This has effectively been achieved by introducing controlled radical polymerization techniques in the 80s and the 90s, which allowed for a minimization of bimolecular termination and an increase of the lifetime of the growing polymer chains through the introduction of dormant forms in the propagating species [42,43]. Essentially, the strategy is to decouple the rates of initiation and termination by either reversible termination or reversible transfer of propagating radicals. Thus, control over molecular weight and polydispersity can effectively be obtained by controlling the propagation step and by suppressing any delayed generation of propagating radicals by uncontrolled chain transfer.
From a historical point of view, Gomberg’s discovery on the equilibrium of trityl radicals with their dimer [44] in 1900, has been one of the origins of the development of CRP, since this was the first demonstration of the possibility of generating relatively stable and inert radicals in solution. 3. Effect of controlled polymerization conditions on MIP synthesis
3.1. Cross-linked networks by CRP and FRP
The basic concept of molecular imprinting is strictly related to the stability of the binding sites generated in a three-dimensional network. Steric and functional memories can effectively be created only if the structure is rigid enough to “freeze” them into the polymeric network. This is normally achieved by polymerizing high amounts of di- or tri-unsaturated cross-linking monomers [1,56,57]. However, in the context of such cross-linked systems, the effect of controlled conditions is less obvious than with linear polymers, where the molecular weights and PDIs can be easily assessed for instance by gel permeation chromatography (GPC). In the case of cross-linked networks, information on the polymer chains or segments between two cross-linking points is much more difficult to obtain due to the insolubility of these polymers. Nevertheless, a number of studies focusing on the effect of CRP on crosslinked networks have been reported, wherein the authors clearly demonstrated the efficiency of controlled polymerization for obtaining more homogeneous structures compared to FRP. As stated in the introduction, the synthesis of MIPs often involves the use of relatively high amount of di- or tri-unsaturated cross-linkers, and the usual premature phase separation occurring in these systems make their study rather complicated. Here we will assess how they also provide the possibility of elaborating macromolecular structures through the synthesis of consecutive polymeric blocks, which means introducing specific functionalities in addition to the recognition properties. This is made possible by the living character of CRP methods, and is particularly relevant since the possibility of decoupling the imprinting step from the design of a macromolecular architecture considerably spreads the application opportunities for MIPs. metadata.abstractText: Since the pioneering work of Wulff and Mosbach more than 30 years ago, molecular imprinting of synthetic polymers has emerged as a robust and convenient way for synthesizing polymeric receptor materials bearing specific recognition sites for target molecules. The resulting materials, molecularly imprinted polymers (MIPs), are therefore commonly referred to as ‘plastic antibodies’. They are obtained by polymerizing a scaffold around a target, or a derivate thereof, which acts as a molecular template. MIPs have been successfully applied in many areas including affinity separation, immunoassays, chemical sensing, solidphase extraction, drug delivery, cell and tissue imaging, direct synthesis and catalysis. In terms of affinity and selectivity, MIPs are on a par with biological receptors like antibodies, and this is accompanied by a superior chemical and physical stability, compatibility with organic media, reusability, easy engineering and low cost. These advantages represent the main reasons for the wide interest raised around molecularly imprinted materials. Mainly produced by free radical polymerization (FRP) of vinyl monomers, MIPs have also taken advantage of the introduction of controlled/living radical polymerization (CRP) techniques, which have literally transformed polymer chemistry over the last decade. This review describes the advantages arising from the use of CRP in synthesizing MIPs, both in terms of sheer binding properties as well as for their remarkable potential for post-polymerization functionalization, for the synthesis of MIP nanomaterials and for the integration of MIPs into composites and hybrid materials. The benefits of using CRP are critically assessed with respect to the still largely applied FRP and guidelines are provided for choosing the most convenient technique to fit a specific targeted application of MIPs. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd.
